channel.title: BUbreakingSectionTwo
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from BUbreakingSectionTwo, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Singapore launches first space agency, joining a Southeast Asian race to tap a fast-growing space sector
item.description: The World Economic Forum predicts the global space economy to exceed $1.8 trillion by 2035, up from $613 billion in 2024.

item.title: What to Know About the Rafah Border Crossing in Gaza
item.description: The only crossing that connects Gaza with Egypt has reopened after nearly a year of closures. The move will allow residents to leave for medical care ...

item.title: Best and Worst Moments From the 2026 Grammys
item.description: Addison Rae tapped into 2000s pop energy, Justin Bieber stripped things down and Bad Bunny got choked up at the 68th annual awards.

item.title: Trump’s plan to make housing affordable is faltering
item.description: “We’re not going to destroy the value of their homes so somebody who didn’t work very hard can buy a home,” Trump said.

item.title: Kennedy Center to close for 2 years for renovations after a wave of canceled shows due to Trump adding his name to the building
item.description: Trump announced the closure days after the premiere of “Melania” a documentary of the first lady was shown at the storied venue.

item.title: 30 years after the founding of ‘Silicon Alley,’ New York’s tech scene is so big it has no center
item.description: Also: All the news and watercooler chat from Fortune.

item.title: Goldman Sachs leads $75 million funding round for Fieldguide, an AI-native accounting and audit platform
item.description: Valued at $700 million, Fieldguide is combating the ‘existential’ talent crisis for the CPA industry.

item.title: Rafah Crossing in Gaza Reopens, Another Step for Fragile Cease-Fire
item.description: Israel and Egypt had disagreed for months about how to resume operations at the Rafah border crossing, which has been largely closed since May 2024.

item.title: Protesters Press Target to Take a Stand Against ICE Crackdown in Minneapolis
item.description: The Minnesota-based retail chain has avoided criticizing anyone, even after federal agents detained two employees at a local store. Its new C.E.O. fac...

item.title: Why The Times Is Expanding Its Supreme Court Coverage
item.description: How four reporters are examining the most secretive branch of government — and the nine justices who shape the law.

item.title: What to Know About the Rafah Border Crossing in Gaza
item.description: The only crossing that connects Gaza with Egypt has reopened after nearly a year of closures. The move will allow residents to leave for medical care ...

item.title: Rafah Crossing in Gaza Reopens, Another Step for Fragile Cease-Fire
item.description: Israel and Egypt had disagreed for months about how to resume operations at the Rafah border crossing, which has been largely closed since May 2024.

item.title: Colombia’s President, an Outspoken Trump Critic, Heads to the White House
item.description: Gustavo Petro of Colombia and President Trump have had a tense relationship that escalated into threats by Mr. Trump, before easing. Anything could ha...

item.title: Laura Fernández Wins Costa Rican Presidency
item.description: Laura Fernández’s victory was driven by a crisis in which Costa Rica’s reputation for peace has been tarred by record-breaking violence.

item.title: Secret Filming of Women Thrives in China as Officials Silence Activists
item.description: Hidden cameras capture women in intimate moments without their consent, yet the authorities do little to stop it.
